 Addressing racism and racial discrimination 
 
 
 
 Report of the Secretary-General 
 
 
 
Summary 
 
The present report is submitted pursuant to General Assembly resolution 78/253, 
in which the Assembly requested the Secretary-General to present for consideration 
at its eightieth session a report entitled “Addressing racism and racial discrimination” 
and ensure that all future reports have that title and focus on combating racism and 
racial discrimination. 
 
In the same resolution, the General Assembly, subject to the provisions of that 
resolution, endorsed the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of 
the 
Advisory 
Committee 
on 
Administrative 
and 
Budgetary 
Questions 
(A/78/7/Add.16) related to the previous report of the Secretary-General (A/78/384). 
The Assembly recalled paragraph 28 of the report of the Advisory Committee and 
requested the Secretary-General to further refine the strategic action plan for 
addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat, 
based on wider data sources and further analysis, and continue to implement the three-
pronged approach for action developed by the Anti-Racism Team to focus on 
combating racism and racial discrimination. 
 
In line with the conclusions of the Advisory Committee, the General Assembly 
requested the Secretary-General to collect more comprehensive and reliable data 
regarding racism and racial discrimination. It recalled paragraph 24 of the report of 
the Committee and decided to review the structure, placement and reporting of the 
Anti-Racism Office, requesting the Secretary-General to propose options for 
consideration during the first part of its resumed eightieth session. 
 
In the present report, the Secretary-General presents the activities undertaken to 
combat racism and racial discrimination in the context of the implementation of the 
strategic action plan since his previous report. In response to the request of the 
General Assembly, the Secretary-General notes that the Anti-Racism Office has 
finalized the refinement of the strategic action plan based on wider data sources and 
continues to implement its three-pronged approach for action. The Secretary-General 


---

2/16 
 
also notes that the Anti-Racism Office, in collaboration with the Department of 
Operational Support and the Office of Information and Communications Technology, 
intends to initiate the collection of data based on race from staff, affiliate personnel 
and job applicants as early as possible in 2026. 
 
The Anti-Racism Office continues to oversee, coordinate and monitor the 
implementation of the strategic action plan as a subprogramme in the Department of 
Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance. The Secretary-General continues to 
reflect on the matter of the placement, structure and reporting lines of the Office 
within the Organization, taking into consideration the context of the UN80 Initiative 
and other ongoing reforms. 
 
 
 
 


---

A/80/469
 
3/16
25-20593 
 
 
I. Introduction 
 
 
1. 
Racism is fundamentally a system of power based on the false notion of racial 
hierarchies and woven into the fabric of societies and institutions to justify the 
subjugation of people of colour. It is deeply rooted in the transatlantic trade in 
enslaved Africans, colonialism and apartheid. It is a system used to justify the unequal 
distribution of power and privilege. This historical legacy continues to have an impact 
on societies today with ongoing, detrimental consequences for racialized 
communities, which remain subjected to pervasive inequities in areas such as 
education, healthcare, employment, justice and wealth. 
2. 
Addressing racism transcends managing individual incidents and requires a 
comprehensive approach to dismantle its historical and systemic roots. In that regard, 
the approach adopted by the Anti-Racism Office is to focus on the future, recognizing 
that no one is born a racist and that racism is a social construct that can, with great 
effort, be eliminated. 
3. 
The presence of racism and racial discrimination in the United Nations system 
undermines the Organization’s standing as a global standard-bearer of human rights. 
Most importantly, racism and racial discrimination debase the Organization’s most 
valuable asset, its staff, thus negatively affecting the effective discharge of its 
mandates. As the world’s premier intergovernmental organization, the United Nations 
is uniquely placed to demonstrate that workplaces with racially inclusive policies that 
respect the dignity of all are better equipped to deliver on global mandates geared 
towards diverse situations and peoples.  
4. 
Over the years, the Secretariat has made efforts to examine and combat racism and 
racial discrimination following General Assembly resolutions 31/26, 53/221 and 76/271. 
However, findings from the 2020 United Nations survey on racism presented in the report 
of the Secretary-General’s Task Force on Addressing Racism and Promoting Dignity for 
All in the United Nations Secretariat confirmed the continued presence of racism and 
racial discrimination within the Organization. Pursuant to Assembly resolution 76/271, 
in 2022 the Secretariat initiated the implementation of the strategic action plan on 
addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat. 
5. 
Following General Assembly resolution 78/253, the Anti-Racism Office was 
established in the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance to 
spearhead and oversee the implementation of the strategic action plan, with its sole 
focus being to address racism and racial discrimination in the workplace. The Office 
operates under the substantive guidance of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-
General for Addressing Racism in the Workplace and the managerial oversight of the 
Under-Secretary-General for Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance. The 
Implementation Steering Group, created in 2022 to oversee the operationalization, 
implementation and mainstreaming of the strategic action plan, continues to provide 
overall leadership and guidance to those charged with the plan’s implementation, in 
addition to providing regular progress reports to the Secretary-General. 
6. 
To ensure the integration and mainstreaming of anti-racism activities throughout 
the Organization, the Anti-Racism Office established a network of anti-racism 
advocates located in duty stations across the global Secretariat, who are the drivers of 
change at the entity level. The Office also collaborates with key departments and 
offices in the Secretariat, such as the Office of Human Resources, the Office of Support 
Operations, the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the 
Office of Internal Oversight Services (OIOS) and the Office of Administration of 
Justice, to examine and reformulate policies, practices and norms that may hinder 
racial diversity and dignity for all. Moreover, close engagement with staff unions and 
affinity groups, as well as United Nations system-wide entities, allows the 
Anti-Racism Office to exchange information on best practices and lessons learned.  


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
4/16 
 
 
II. The imperative to address racism and racial discrimination 
 
 
7. 
In 2021, the Secretary-General issued the report on addressing racism and 
promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat and its corresponding strategic 
action plan. The need to address racism and racial discrimination was also underscored 
by the Joint Inspection Unit in its note entitled “Review of measures and mechanisms for 
addressing racism and racial discrimination in United Nations system organizations: 
managing for achieving organizational effectiveness” (JIU/NOTE/2022/1/Rev.1). Staff 
views expressed through the racism survey undertaken in 2020 and the staff engagement 
survey in 2021 confirmed the urgency of combating racism in the Secretariat. 
8. 
Today, the imperative to address racism and racial discrimination in the 
Organization remains, as attested by: (a) the staff engagement survey conducted in 
2024; (b) the continuing engagements of the Special Adviser with United Nations 
staff across the Secretariat; and (c) a recent analysis undertaken by the Secretariat of 
the staff composition between 2023 and 2025.  
 
 
 
Results of the 2024 staff engagement survey 
 
9. 
Since 2021, the United Nations staff engagement survey has included questions 
on racism and racial discrimination. The responses are a key tool to monitor and 
evaluate experiences of discrimination, identify ongoing issues relating to reporting 
misconduct, and understand whether any progress has been made in addressing racism 
and racial discrimination in the Secretariat. 
10. The 2024 survey showed that racism and racial discrimination remain key focus 
areas for Secretariat staff. The survey garnered a response rate of 42 per cent 
(approximately 15,000 staff members) with staff who self-identified as “Black or 
Afro-descent” and “White” having the highest participation rates. Secretariat staff 
who responded to the staff engagement survey self-identified as follows:

11. 
Questions in the staff engagement survey relating to racism and racial 
discrimination addressed issues such as tolerance of racial discrimination in the 
workplace, leadership commitment to addressing racism and racial discrimination, 
impact of training programmes, and understanding of where to report racism and 
racial discrimination. Survey respondents who reported having been discriminated 
against were asked further questions on how they responded to the discrimination, 
whether they had reported it, and satisfaction with how reports were handled. 


---

A/80/469
 
5/16
25-20593 
 
12. The 2024 survey results demonstrated that racism and discrimination continue 
to be prevalent concerns for Secretariat staff. Results remained largely consistent with 
trends measured by previous staff engagement surveys starting in 2021. Twenty-five 
per cent of respondents in 2024 felt that they were not guaranteed equal opportunities 
at work due to a number of factors, including race, skin colour and national or ethnic 
origin. Findings also showed that 33 per cent of those respondents who reported that 
they had been discriminated against indicated that critical incidents or misconduct 
were not reported due to a lack of trust in the reporting system, with 48 per cent 
indicating a fear of retaliation. Over half of respondents who indicated that they had 
reported cases expressed dissatisfaction with how incidents were resolved. 
13. The results of the 2024 staff engagement survey demonstrate the need for 
continued engagement with staff and stakeholders on all three pillars of the work of 
the Anti-Racism Office (advocacy and awareness-raising, transparency and 
institutional reform, and accountability and racial justice) to improve perceptions and 
experiences related to racism and racial discrimination in the Secretariat.  
 
 
 
Special Adviser’s engagement with staff and the United Nations system 
 
14. To advance the strategic action plan and directly engage with United Nations 
staff and leadership in the field, the Special Adviser undertook a mission to Ethiopia, 
Kenya and Somalia from 28 April to 6 May 2025. The mission was aimed at evaluating 
progress in implementing the strategic action plan and better understanding staff 
experiences and perceptions of racism in the workplace. It included engagements with 
personnel in the Economic Commission for Africa, the United Nations Environment 
Programme, the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat), the 
United Nations Office at Nairobi, the United Nations Support Office in Somalia and 
the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia. 
15. During these engagements, staff members raised several issues, pointing to 
structural disparities across various recruitment and human resources management 
practices, as well as incidents of overt racist behaviour in the workplace which have 
led to significant mental health issues. A prevalent fear of retaliation still prevents 
many from coming forward to report incidents of racial discrimination. More broadly, 
staff members relayed fear and uncertainty about the impact of UN80 reforms on 
them, which might have a disproportional impact on people of colour. In response, 
the Special Adviser reiterated that, as the Organization underwent restructuring, it 
must be highly aware of and actively guard against reproducing old racial hierarchies. 
Ultimately, the success of this reform hinged on its ability to decisively correct 
historical exclusions, rather than inadvertently entrench them.  
16. Specific concerns raised by staff included stalled implementation of the strategic 
action plan and marginalization in relation to mobility and access to global roles. Staff 
have spoken openly – often identifying themselves – about racial bias in deployment 
and promotion, lack of inclusive leadership development, exclusion of General 
Service staff and contractors from anti-racism efforts, and fears that UN80 reforms 
could reverse recent gains. Some staff felt that training and travel opportunities were 
also clouded by perceptions of racial bias. On a positive note, one anti-racism 
advocate created the Supporting Holistic Anti-Racism Efforts (SHARE) Team, which 
was recognized as a model to be replicated in other entities. 
17. The Special Adviser also convened hybrid town hall meetings that reached 
personnel in the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, the Department of 
Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, the Department of Peace Operations, 
the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, the Department for General 
Assembly and Conference Management, the Department of Global Communications, 
the Department of Safety and Security and the Development Coordination Office. The 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
6/16 
 
Special Adviser also held virtual town hall meetings for the United Nations Assistance 
Mission in Afghanistan and the United Nations Mission in South Sudan. At these 
meetings, concerns raised by staff included subtle but entrenched racism in 
recruitment and daily interactions, denial of racism by some managers, burden-of-
proof challenges, exclusion of national staff perspectives, elitism favouring graduates 
of prestigious global North universities, and tokenistic implementation of diversity 
measures. At one such meeting, specific allegations of racism were raised openly 
against a manager who was in the room. 
18. Across all duty stations, staff consistently requested stronger accountability 
mechanisms. They also directed complaints and reported racism to the Special 
Adviser and occasionally to the Anti-Racism Office, despite neither being mandated 
to process them. Submissions included allegations of racial discrimination in the 
workplace and racial bias in appointments and promotions, and, where appropriate, 
formal complaints were shared with OIOS for proper follow-up and investigation. 
However, in many instances staff members just wanted to share their experiences and 
refused to lodge formal complaints due to a lack of trust in the system of 
administration of justice and fear of potential reprisals.  
19. 
Beyond the Secretariat, the Special Adviser delivered a presentation to the United 
Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination in Santiago in May 2024, 
highlighting the urgency of addressing racism across the United Nations system and of 
promoting a coordinated response. She further engaged with agencies, funds and 
programmes through the Geneva Alliance against Racism and participated in the senior 
women’s leadership retreats organized by the Deputy Secretary-General, to advance 
discussions on inclusive leadership and accountability. The Special Adviser also met 
with heads of United Nations agencies, funds and programmes based in East Africa 
during her visit to Nairobi. In addition, the Special Adviser’s team gave briefings on 
the work of the Anti-Racism Office at multiple orientation programmes organized by 
the United Nations System Staff College for Junior Professional Officers across the 
United Nations system.  
 
 
 
Analysis of recent staff composition 
 
20. In the absence of race-related data in the Organization’s enterprise systems, 
geographical regions of Member States are used as a proxy. It is crucial to 
acknowledge that geographical regions of Member States as a proxy for race-related 
data do not provide a full understanding of racial identity. It is also understood that 
geographical regions are not homogeneous and exhibit a degree of racial diversity. 
While the data analysis does not directly measure the impact of systemic and 
structural racism on the Organization’s recruitment policies, processes and 
procedures, it does offer valuable indicative evidence regarding the application of the 
staff selection system based on geographical regions of Member States. The analysis 
follows a similar approach to that in the reports of the Secretary-General on the 
composition of the Secretariat: staff demographics. 
21. 
To implement its mandates, the Secretariat relied on a workforce of 35,231 as at 
31 December 2024, including 881 staff who supplemented the workforce with 
temporary assistance for meetings, staff on when-actually-employed contracts and staff 
with one-dollar-per-year contracts. Among those staff members, 41 per cent are serving 
in the Professional and higher categories. Figure I shows the regional distribution of 
staff employed in the Secretariat in the Professional and higher categories.

23. Regarding trends observed relating to applications for positions and selection 
trends in recruitment processes, an analysis was conducted of the number of 
applicants from various geographical regions and selection outcomes for job openings 
in the Professional and higher categories across all entities within the Secretariat, 
including peacekeeping operations, special political missions, other political

24. Figure II and table 2 contain a summary of the number of applications received, 
screened, assessed, endorsed and selected for job openings posted between January 
2020 and December 2024 in the Professional and higher categories, grouped by 
geographical region of the applicant’s country of nationality. 
25.

III. Activities undertaken to address racism and racial 
discrimination in the United Nations Secretariat 
 
 
27. The Secretary-General’s strategic action plan on addressing racism and 
promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat is the road map for targeted 
actions to combat racism and racial discrimination at the interpersonal, institutional, 
structural and systemic levels. The Anti-Racism Office has been spearheading the 
implementation of the strategic action plan using resources approved by the General 
Assembly in its resolution 78/253. 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
10/16 
 
28. The Anti-Racism Office continued to implement the strategic action plan through 
its three-pronged approach, consisting of the following action pillars: advocacy and 
awareness-raising; transparency and institutional reform; and accountability and racial 
justice. The Office undertook its activities in collaboration with anti-racism advocates 
and relevant partners across the Secretariat. To promote engagement, coordination and 
complementarity and to prevent duplication, the Office convenes several recurring 
meetings: quarterly meetings with anti-racism advocates, principals of relevant 
entities involved in implementing the strategic action plan, and working-level, 
thematic working groups tied to the three aforementioned action pillars; biannual 
meetings with staff unions, national staff associations, and staff affinity groups such 
as the United Nations People of African Descent and the United Nations Asia Network 
for Diversity and Inclusion; and an annual retreat that brings together all designated 
actors from various entities involved in the implementation of this mandate. In 
addition, the Special Adviser annually convenes and chairs three meetings of the 
Implementation Steering Group, which is composed of senior United Nations leaders 
and external experts and provides high-level guidance for the activities of the 
Anti-Racism Office and its partners across the Secretariat. All these meetings provide 
structured frameworks for multiple stakeholders to discuss, build and coordinate 
synergies towards the effective implementation of the strategic action plan.  
29. As requested by the General Assembly in its resolution 78/253, the Anti-Racism 
Office has refined the strategic action plan. This refinement does not aim to replace 
the existing action plan but rather to provide an update focused on three key areas: 
 
• Ensuring that the plan is focused exclusively on addressing racism and racial 
discrimination 
 
• Updating the definitions of critical concepts related to racism and racial 
discrimination to account for evolving understandings 
 
• Including additional implementation actions 
The refinement of the strategic action plan was undertaken through a consultative 
process with the anti-racism advocates and other relevant stakeholders in the Secretariat. 
30. The activities undertaken by the Anti-Racism Office in collaboration with its 
partners in the Secretariat and the broader United Nations system during the reporting 
period are presented below under headings corresponding to the three action pillars. 
 
 
 
A. Advocacy and awareness-raising 
 
 
31. 
Through activities aimed at raising awareness about racism and racial 
discrimination, as well as fostering dialogue and learning, the work under this pillar is 
focused on changing the organizational culture and building a workplace free of racism. 
32. In terms of training, the Anti-Racism Office, in collaboration with the Office of 
Human Resources, finalized the Secretariat’s first ever course on racism, entitled 
“Addressing racism and racial discrimination in the workplace”, which was launched 
on 4 December 2025 in English and French, with other official languages to follow. 
This online self-paced basic awareness course is intended to be made mandatory for 
all personnel.  
33. The Anti-Racism Office also organized, in collaboration with an external 
consultancy firm, various anti-racism training programmes in 2023, 2024 and 2025. 
These were directed at specialized groups such as the anti-racism advocates, senior 
leaders, managers at the D-1 and D-2 levels, staff counsellors, conduct and discipline 
officers, investigators, human resources chiefs, legal officers and members of the 
Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services. Topics included 


---

A/80/469
 
11/16
25-20593 
 
foundational anti-racism skills, psychological safety, the role of the United Nations 
in addressing racism, anti-racism leadership, anti-racism allyship, and racial healing. 
Participants were also trained on how to facilitate difficult discussions and foster 
constructive dialogue. These training courses were taken by 531 participants, 
including 79 at the Under-Secretary-General and Assistant Secretary-General levels 
and additional colleagues from the wider United Nations system.  
34. Meanwhile, in 2025 the Department of Operational Support launched a course 
entitled “Brave conversations: building thriving teams together”, which contained 
anti-racism elements and was accompanied by an interactive card exercise designed 
to spark open dialogue, critical thinking and meaningful reflections around the 
concept of psychological safety. The Department also published an updated and 
enhanced version of “The art of hiring talent”, incorporating recommendations and 
best practices from the Anti-Racism Office on staff selection.  
35. Regarding the creation of spaces and platforms for staff to share experiences, ask 
questions and contribute to shaping the Organization’s anti-racism agenda, the 
Anti-Racism Office organized 10 advocacy and awareness-raising events, including 
the “United against racism” live talks and anti-racism conversations. Topics included 
addressing racial bias, reporting racism complaints, promoting upstanding and allyship 
and decolonizing minds. During these events, the Anti-Racism Office engaged a range 
of distinguished external speakers who interacted directly with staff and responded to 
their questions, fostering deeper reflection on racism, identity and justice across the 
United Nations. Among them were Djamila Ribeiro (Brazil), philosopher, writer and 
activist; Trevor Manuel (South Africa), former minister; Mamadou Diouf (Senegal), 
historian at Columbia University; Gay McDougall (United States of America), 
member of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination; Constance 
Mayer (United States of America), Chief of Diversity and Inclusion at the Department 
of State; Afua Hirsch (United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland), 
journalist, author and broadcaster; Albie Sachs (South Africa), former judge of the 
Constitutional Court; and Penelope Andrews (South Africa), law professor and 
Director of New York Law School’s Racial Justice Project. These sessions reached 
over 27,000 staff members globally and generated more than 4,000 comments and 
questions. The United against Racism iSeek page and dedicated UN Web TV channel 
received more than 12,000 visits, demonstrating sustained staff interest. 
36. The United Nations anti-racism advocates are the drivers of the implementation 
of the strategic action plan at the entity level. During the reporting period, the 
Anti-Racism Office expanded this global network, which now includes 146 
anti-racism advocates and alternates as well as over 75 working group members 
serving across 85 Secretariat entities worldwide. To strengthen their capacity, the 
Anti-Racism Office works closely with the network, providing the advocates with 
training, an online resource hub and a platform for internal communication.  
37. Across duty stations, the anti-racism advocates organized a variety of activities. 
For example, in Mogadishu, they organized an anti-racism retreat and a series of staff 
discussions, established a library of anti-racism literature to foster learning and worked 
with leadership to establish measures for anti-racism accountability. In Entebbe, 
Uganda, advocates organized film screenings followed by discussions to raise 
awareness. In Geneva, in addition to entity-focused training and discussions, they 
organized an anti-racism-focused picnic for staff to support each other. In Naqurah, 
Lebanon, the advocates formed dedicated working groups of staff volunteers who 
organized regular dialogues on anti-racism. Meanwhile, the anti-racism working group 
in Vienna was instrumental in constituting peer support groups for colleagues who 
experience racial discrimination. Other advocates incorporated anti-racism into 
induction training, conducted internal surveys to assess staff perceptions of racism, 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
12/16 
 
created podcasts, produced articles to raise awareness about racism in the workplace, 
and worked closely with their senior leaders to develop entity-specific action plans. A 
major task being undertaken by the advocates is the Diversity in Leadership 
Transparency Project, which entails the publication of the names, photos, nationalities, 
levels and titles of all senior leaders at the D-1 level and above. As of November 2025, 
50 per cent of the 85 entities have completed the project. Overall, despite all the 
challenges they face, the anti-racism advocates have consistently served as the 
backbone for implementing the strategic action plan within their respective entities. 
38. The Anti-Racism Office hosted the United Nations Conference on Addressing 
Racism and Promoting Dignity for All at the Secretariat in Lisbon from 9 to 12 June 
2025. The conference was made possible through the support of the Government of 
Portugal and an additional contribution from the Government of the United Kingdom 
of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The conference brought together 50 
participants from duty stations across Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America, the Middle 
East and North America, the majority of whom were anti-racism advocates. The 
conference was aimed at sharing information and fostering a cohesive anti-racism 
community with a common vision to accelerate the implementation of the strategic 
action plan. Participants had the opportunity to engage with guest speakers from the 
host country, South Africa and the United Kingdom from sectors as diverse as 
government, civil society, academia, corporate business and the arts. The discussions 
covered topics such as the systemic and historical nature of racism; racial bias in 
recruitment and staff management processes; accountability and racial justice; 
collection and analysis of race data; and mediation support and anti-retaliation 
mechanisms. Tangible outcomes included a clear implementation timeline for 
activities in 2026–2028; a robust engagement strategy for anti-racism stakeholders 
across the Secretariat; the approval of a toolkit for anti-racism advocates entitled 
“Facilitating discussions on race, racism and racial discrimination in the workplace”; 
and a symbolic pledge to combat racism and racial discrimination in the Secretariat 
that was signed by all participants.  
 
 
 
B. Transparency and institutional reform  
 
 
39. The work under this pillar is focused on collecting and analysing data to 
understand the racial composition of the Secretariat's workforce and applicant pool 
and examine potential bias in recruitment, appointments, promotions, mobility, roster 
management and career satisfaction opportunities. This pillar also addresses the 
review of institutional policies and practices that may appear neutral but could lead 
to racial inequities. The ultimate aim is to identify systemic or institutional 
discriminatory provisions and subsequently, where necessary, amend existing policies 
or introduce new ones. 
40. Key stakeholders in this pillar include the Anti-Racism Office, the Department 
of Operational Support and the Office of Human Resources. The Organization, 
following a number of comprehensive reviews on reducing recruitment bias, is 
operationalizing key recommendations. New elements include requiring geographical 
diversity on interview panels and moving to a new structured interview model under 
the staff selection system policy effective 1 October 2025. The Department of 
Operational Support is also undertaking measures to reduce bias, including racial 
bias, in the generic rostering process and developing a machine learning framework 
to identify and measure potential bias in recruitment. Furthermore, in June 2025, the 
Talent Finder tool was implemented to proactively enable hiring teams to reach out 
to qualified candidates from unrepresented and underrepresented nationalities.  


---

A/80/469
 
13/16
25-20593 
 
41. Moreover, the staff selection 2.0 project is implementing key initiatives to 
remove barriers in recruitment and make recruitment more effective, fair, efficient 
and agile. Staff selection 2.0 is expected to have a positive impact in reducing 
potential racial discrimination in recruitment. Initiatives under staff selection 2.0 
include undertaking inclusive job analysis and updating job profiles to provide for 
skills-based recruitment; developing options for assessment methodologies to fulfil 
the universality objective, including interview methods; professionalizing recruiters; 
and enhancing data capabilities to allow real-time monitoring, with a view to ensuring 
that the recruitment process is evaluated for fairness and decisions are continuously 
monitored for potential bias and accuracy, permitting evidence-informed adjustments.  
42. Regarding data collection and analysis, and in response to the General 
Assembly’s request in resolution 78/253, the Anti-Racism Office, in collaboration 
with the Department of Operational Support and the Office of Information and 
Communications Technology, established a framework for the collection of race data 
from staff, affiliate personnel and job applicants. The collection of race data is 
expected to begin via Inspira as early as possible in 2026. 
43. Race data will be provided voluntarily, used in an anonymized and aggregated 
form, kept confidential and used only to understand racism and racial discrimination 
in the Secretariat and to take remedial actions to reverse patterns of racism and racial 
discrimination and their trends. This information will not be used in connection with 
any individual human resources management processes. It will not be visible to 
recruiters or hiring managers in recruitment, selection or promotion processes, or to 
managers in the performance management, retention or separation processes. A 
comprehensive racial diversity baseline report will be produced with the aim of 
identifying patterns of systemic institutional racial bias across the Secretariat. To 
encourage staff to disclose their racial identities, the Anti-Racism Office is 
proactively developing an internal communications campaign in collaboration with 
the Department of Global Communications to build trust and encourage participation. 
 
 
 
C. Accountability and racial justice  
 
 
44. The work under this pillar is focused on developing measures to address racism 
and racial discrimination and ensure accountability from both leadership and staff. It 
also addresses issues related to the internal administration of justice system, aiming 
to promote racial justice and fostering a safe institutional environment for making 
complaints and reporting incidents of racism. Racial healing and protection and 
support mechanisms for staff members affected by racial discrimination are also 
critical aspects of this pillar. 
45. The review of Secretary-General’s bulletin ST/SGB/2019/8 to include a 
definition of racial discrimination as prohibited conduct for all staff is being 
undertaken by the Anti-Racism Office in collaboration with the Office of Human 
Resources, OIOS, the Office of Legal Affairs and other key stakeholders. Proposed 
amendments to the bulletin went through an entity-wide consultation process prior to 
further review. To support the review, the Anti-Racism Office conducted research on 
definitions used by other United Nations agencies and multilateral institutions. This 
research contributed to framing the discussions between stakeholders and highlighted 
that, once the revised ST/SGB/2019/8 is promulgated, the Anti-Racism Office is to 
develop, in consultation with key stakeholders, an accompanying guideline to assist 
with providing examples of racial discrimination. 
46. Regarding data on complaints including elements of racism and racial discrimination, 
OIOS received 132 such complaints from 30 September 2023 to 30 September 2025. Of 
the 132 complaints, 38 were decided for investigation by OIOS, 61 were referred to the 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
14/16 
 
relevant responsible official for review and appropriate action, 32 were closed, and 
1 remained in intake. During the same period, 37 investigations were completed. The 
number of complaints received remained relatively stable over the two-year period, 
although a spike in reporting was observed in the last quarter of 2024, bringing the total 
number of complaints for 2024 to a record high of 81. This increase was observed in the 
months following online events on accountability organized by the Anti-Racism Office. 
Between 1 January and 30 September 2025, 46 complaints were received. Meanwhile, the 
average time to complete investigations improved during the two-year period, from 12.5 
months to 10.9 months, which is lower than the overall average completion time for all 
types of misconduct. OIOS also organized training for its investigators to sensitize them to 
how racism manifests itself and on how racism may best be investigated. 
47. To reinforce a system-wide zero-tolerance policy on racism, the Office of 
Administration of Justice, through the Caselaw portal for United Nations Dispute 
Tribunal and United Nations Appeals Tribunal judgments, makes a search available 
for the category “Discrimination and other improper motives” and the subcategory 
“Race”. A search for the term “racism” reveals that 35 judgments from both Tribunals 
referred to racism in the context of the parties’ submissions and/or in the Tribunal’s 
considerations. This does not necessarily mean that the Tribunals identified racism as 
a motive of discrimination, but that reference was made to racism in the judgments. 
48. The Office of Staff Legal Assistance collected data on cases involving allegations 
of racism, having received 33 such cases between 1 December 2024 and 25 September 
2025. Furthermore, the Office successfully represented a staff member in a non-selection 
case that raised several issues, including issues relating to racial bias, and the Appeals 
Tribunal ultimately found in favour of the staff member, due to a number of factors. 
49. In 2024, the Administrative Law Division of the Office of Human Resources started 
tracking cases in which the established misconduct related to race, nationality or ethnic 
origin. In 2024, three cases involving racist or racially insensitive behaviour warranted 
separation from service, and one case resulted in a written censure. In addition, and as 
part of an expansion of the ClearCheck system, the Division included “racism and racial 
discrimination” in the ClearCheck database as a type of misconduct warranting an end to 
a working relationship with the United Nations. As at 1 November 2025, 30 participating 
United Nations entities had joined ClearCheck 2.0. As at the same date, the ClearCheck 
database contained the name and related information of one individual who had been 
subject to a substantiated allegation of racism and racial discrimination. 
50. As the informal part of the system of administration of justice, the Office of the 
United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services is available to personnel who 
have concerns related to prohibited conduct, including racial discrimination, under 
Secretary-General’s bulletin ST/SGB/2019/8. Under the zero-tolerance approach, 
most cases related to allegations of racial discrimination are directed to the formal 
complaints channel; nevertheless, some employees have turned to the Office after 
experiencing racial discrimination and/or racist behaviour motivated by conscious or 
unconscious beliefs and biases. In such cases, the Office seeks to facilitate 
conversations to enhance understanding and awareness, leading to reflection and 
behavioural change by the alleged offenders.  
51. In carrying out its advisory function, the Ethics Office advocates against racism 
and racial discrimination through its advisory and outreach activities at duty stations 
and locations across the global Secretariat. Furthermore, the Office’s mandate of 
implementing the Organization’s policy on protection against retaliation also 
encourages staff to speak up, with the aim of protecting staff who report misconduct 
within the parameters of the policy. 
 
 


---

A/80/469
 
15/16
25-20593 
 
 
IV. Main challenges and the way forward 
 
 
52. The Anti-Racism Office continues to face several constraints that affect the scope 
and pace of its work, necessitating strategic adjustments. Despite the progress achieved 
in 2024 and 2025, persistent liquidity constraints have challenged the Office’s capacity 
to work more effectively. Given the small size of the Office, its operational success in 
carrying out this large and vital mandate benefits much from the performance of the 
anti-racism advocates situated across various entities. However, the performance of 
this network of advocates remains quite uneven. Although some advocates are 
performing very well, a significant number still encounter difficulties in securing 
leadership support and fully understanding the mandate and at times are overwhelmed 
by the sheer magnitude and complexity of the task, which they undertake in addition 
to their regular responsibilities. Convening the advocates every two years in in-person 
gatherings will be important. The conference in Lisbon proved instrumental in 
successfully energizing and cultivating a cohesive community among the advocates, 
enabling open discussions about challenges, lessons learned and best practices. 
However, organizing future gatherings of this nature poses a challenge because they 
require external funding. In that regard, the Secretary-General welcomes voluntary 
contributions from Member States to organize the next United Nations Conference on 
Addressing Racism and Promoting Dignity for All at the Secretariat. 
53. A fundamental requisite for understanding and addressing systemic and 
structural racism within the Secretariat is the collection and analysis of race data from 
staff, affiliate personnel and job applicants. Although such data will be strictly 
anonymized and will not be used in connection with any individual human resources 
management processes, the Office anticipates some hesitance to participate on the 
part of those being asked to submit data, due to insufficient understanding of the 
data’s intended use. Resources are required to explain this aspect as widely as 
possible. Since this exercise will be voluntary, staff and applicants must feel a high 
degree of comfort and trust to share their racial identities. Insufficient participation 
will severely hinder proper scientific analysis, preventing the identification of 
systemic inequities.  
54. Talking about racism involves inherent sensitivities, and staff have consistently 
expressed appreciation for the in-person engagement with the Special Adviser, the 
Anti-Racism Office and anti-racism advocates as they provide critical spaces for open 
dialogue and trust-building. In that regard, investing in such in-person engagement 
wherever possible will be important. 
55. Looking ahead, the Anti-Racism Office is planning its next phase of work, 
focused on ongoing concrete implementation of the strategic action plan and capacity-
building. It plans to continue working closely with the anti-racism advocates and 
other key stakeholders to execute its refined implementation timeline for the next 
three years. This timeline details specific actions that have been thoroughly discussed 
and agreed upon with partners, ensuring that they are implementable, barring any 
unforeseen circumstances. 
56. A major future effort will be dedicated to strengthening the capacity of the 
advocates to discharge their functions effectively. This focus is based on the 
understanding that effective and sustainable institutional transformation must be 
grounded in bottom-up initiatives and local ownership. Another critical area of 
intervention will be reducing racial bias in recruitment and staff management 
processes. This will require working more effectively with the Office of Human 
Resources and the Department of Operational Support to review policies and practices. 
Similarly, reinforcing leadership accountability and ensuring the provision of safe 
environments for staff to lodge complaints and report racist incidents will be vital. 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
16/16 
 
Crucially, under this pillar, faster resolution of cases must also be prioritized. To 
achieve this, engagement with OIOS, the Administrative Law Division of the Office 
of Human Resources and the Office of Administration of Justice will be fundamental. 
57. The successful execution of the strategic action plan ultimately hinges on a 
sustained, visible commitment from all levels of the Secretariat, particularly senior 
leadership. By investing in the dedicated anti-racism advocates, enhancing 
transparency with objective data analysis, and ensuring robust accountability 
mechanisms, the Anti-Racism Office can spearhead the necessary systemic 
transformation. The path forward requires collective responsibility to foster an 
organizational culture free of racial discrimination, where dignity and respect are 
lived realities for every staff member. 
 
 
 
V. Action to be taken by the General Assembly 
 
 
58. The General Assembly is requested to take note of the present report. 
 
"}

## Summary — `A/80/469`
The SG report, mandated by GA resolution 78/253, refines and implements a three-pillar plan—advocacy, transparency/institutional reform, and accountability—to combat racism in the UN Secretariat, with race-data collection to begin in 2026. It notes persistent discrimination (2024 staff survey and workforce analytics showing underrepresentation and selection biases), advances training and recruitment reforms, strengthens accountability (including revising ST/SGB/2019/8), highlights resource and trust challenges, and invites the GA to take note.

- Key findings: 25% of staff felt unequal opportunities; 48% feared retaliation; over half dissatisfied with case handling.
- Workforce analytics: Africans/Asians hold fewer P‑5/D‑1/D‑2 roles relative to their share; selections favored Europeans (35% of selections vs 24% of applications) and European‑educated candidates (53% selections vs 38% applications).
- Actions: Mandatory e‑learning launched (Dec 2025); expanded advocate network; 2025 Lisbon anti‑racism conference; recruitment reforms (diverse panels, structured interviews, Staff Selection 2.0, Talent Finder, ML bias detection).
- Accountability: Revising ST/SGB/2019/8 to define racial discrimination; OIOS logged 132 complaints (avg investigation time down to 10.9 months); ClearCheck includes racism/racial discrimination.
- Challenges/next steps: Liquidity constraints, uneven advocate capacity, need for high participation in race-data disclosure and sustained leadership commitment.

result.text:
United Nations 
A/80/469
 
 
General Assembly 
Distr.: General 
17 December 2025 
Original: English

*2520593* 
 
 
Eightieth session 
Agenda item 136 
Proposed programme budget for 2026 
 
 
 
 
 Addressing racism and racial discrimination 
 
 
 
 Report of the Secretary-General 
 
 
 
Summary 
 
The present report is submitted pursuant to General Assembly resolution 78/253, 
in which the Assembly requested the Secretary-General to present for consideration 
at its eightieth session a report entitled “Addressing racism and racial discrimination” 
and ensure that all future reports have that title and focus on combating racism and 
racial discrimination. 
 
In the same resolution, the General Assembly, subject to the provisions of that 
resolution, endorsed the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of 
the 
Advisory 
Committee 
on 
Administrative 
and 
Budgetary 
Questions 
(A/78/7/Add.16) related to the previous report of the Secretary-General (A/78/384). 
The Assembly recalled paragraph 28 of the report of the Advisory Committee and 
requested the Secretary-General to further refine the strategic action plan for 
addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat, 
based on wider data sources and further analysis, and continue to implement the three-
pronged approach for action developed by the Anti-Racism Team to focus on 
combating racism and racial discrimination. 
 
In line with the conclusions of the Advisory Committee, the General Assembly 
requested the Secretary-General to collect more comprehensive and reliable data 
regarding racism and racial discrimination. It recalled paragraph 24 of the report of 
the Committee and decided to review the structure, placement and reporting of the 
Anti-Racism Office, requesting the Secretary-General to propose options for 
consideration during the first part of its resumed eightieth session. 
 
In the present report, the Secretary-General presents the activities undertaken to 
combat racism and racial discrimination in the context of the implementation of the 
strategic action plan since his previous report. In response to the request of the 
General Assembly, the Secretary-General notes that the Anti-Racism Office has 
finalized the refinement of the strategic action plan based on wider data sources and 
continues to implement its three-pronged approach for action. The Secretary-General 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
2/16 
 
also notes that the Anti-Racism Office, in collaboration with the Department of 
Operational Support and the Office of Information and Communications Technology, 
intends to initiate the collection of data based on race from staff, affiliate personnel 
and job applicants as early as possible in 2026. 
 
The Anti-Racism Office continues to oversee, coordinate and monitor the 
implementation of the strategic action plan as a subprogramme in the Department of 
Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance. The Secretary-General continues to 
reflect on the matter of the placement, structure and reporting lines of the Office 
within the Organization, taking into consideration the context of the UN80 Initiative 
and other ongoing reforms. 
 
 
 
 


---

A/80/469
 
3/16
25-20593 
 
 
I. Introduction 
 
 
1. 
Racism is fundamentally a system of power based on the false notion of racial 
hierarchies and woven into the fabric of societies and institutions to justify the 
subjugation of people of colour. It is deeply rooted in the transatlantic trade in 
enslaved Africans, colonialism and apartheid. It is a system used to justify the unequal 
distribution of power and privilege. This historical legacy continues to have an impact 
on societies today with ongoing, detrimental consequences for racialized 
communities, which remain subjected to pervasive inequities in areas such as 
education, healthcare, employment, justice and wealth. 
2. 
Addressing racism transcends managing individual incidents and requires a 
comprehensive approach to dismantle its historical and systemic roots. In that regard, 
the approach adopted by the Anti-Racism Office is to focus on the future, recognizing 
that no one is born a racist and that racism is a social construct that can, with great 
effort, be eliminated. 
3. 
The presence of racism and racial discrimination in the United Nations system 
undermines the Organization’s standing as a global standard-bearer of human rights. 
Most importantly, racism and racial discrimination debase the Organization’s most 
valuable asset, its staff, thus negatively affecting the effective discharge of its 
mandates. As the world’s premier intergovernmental organization, the United Nations 
is uniquely placed to demonstrate that workplaces with racially inclusive policies that 
respect the dignity of all are better equipped to deliver on global mandates geared 
towards diverse situations and peoples.  
4. 
Over the years, the Secretariat has made efforts to examine and combat racism and 
racial discrimination following General Assembly resolutions 31/26, 53/221 and 76/271. 
However, findings from the 2020 United Nations survey on racism presented in the report 
of the Secretary-General’s Task Force on Addressing Racism and Promoting Dignity for 
All in the United Nations Secretariat confirmed the continued presence of racism and 
racial discrimination within the Organization. Pursuant to Assembly resolution 76/271, 
in 2022 the Secretariat initiated the implementation of the strategic action plan on 
addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat. 
5. 
Following General Assembly resolution 78/253, the Anti-Racism Office was 
established in the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance to 
spearhead and oversee the implementation of the strategic action plan, with its sole 
focus being to address racism and racial discrimination in the workplace. The Office 
operates under the substantive guidance of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-
General for Addressing Racism in the Workplace and the managerial oversight of the 
Under-Secretary-General for Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance. The 
Implementation Steering Group, created in 2022 to oversee the operationalization, 
implementation and mainstreaming of the strategic action plan, continues to provide 
overall leadership and guidance to those charged with the plan’s implementation, in 
addition to providing regular progress reports to the Secretary-General. 
6. 
To ensure the integration and mainstreaming of anti-racism activities throughout 
the Organization, the Anti-Racism Office established a network of anti-racism 
advocates located in duty stations across the global Secretariat, who are the drivers of 
change at the entity level. The Office also collaborates with key departments and 
offices in the Secretariat, such as the Office of Human Resources, the Office of Support 
Operations, the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the 
Office of Internal Oversight Services (OIOS) and the Office of Administration of 
Justice, to examine and reformulate policies, practices and norms that may hinder 
racial diversity and dignity for all. Moreover, close engagement with staff unions and 
affinity groups, as well as United Nations system-wide entities, allows the 
Anti-Racism Office to exchange information on best practices and lessons learned.  


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
4/16 
 
 
II. The imperative to address racism and racial discrimination 
 
 
7. 
In 2021, the Secretary-General issued the report on addressing racism and 
promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat and its corresponding strategic 
action plan. The need to address racism and racial discrimination was also underscored 
by the Joint Inspection Unit in its note entitled “Review of measures and mechanisms for 
addressing racism and racial discrimination in United Nations system organizations: 
managing for achieving organizational effectiveness” (JIU/NOTE/2022/1/Rev.1). Staff 
views expressed through the racism survey undertaken in 2020 and the staff engagement 
survey in 2021 confirmed the urgency of combating racism in the Secretariat. 
8. 
Today, the imperative to address racism and racial discrimination in the 
Organization remains, as attested by: (a) the staff engagement survey conducted in 
2024; (b) the continuing engagements of the Special Adviser with United Nations 
staff across the Secretariat; and (c) a recent analysis undertaken by the Secretariat of 
the staff composition between 2023 and 2025.  
 
 
 
Results of the 2024 staff engagement survey 
 
9. 
Since 2021, the United Nations staff engagement survey has included questions 
on racism and racial discrimination. The responses are a key tool to monitor and 
evaluate experiences of discrimination, identify ongoing issues relating to reporting 
misconduct, and understand whether any progress has been made in addressing racism 
and racial discrimination in the Secretariat. 
10. The 2024 survey showed that racism and racial discrimination remain key focus 
areas for Secretariat staff. The survey garnered a response rate of 42 per cent 
(approximately 15,000 staff members) with staff who self-identified as “Black or 
Afro-descent” and “White” having the highest participation rates. Secretariat staff 
who responded to the staff engagement survey self-identified as follows:

11. 
Questions in the staff engagement survey relating to racism and racial 
discrimination addressed issues such as tolerance of racial discrimination in the 
workplace, leadership commitment to addressing racism and racial discrimination, 
impact of training programmes, and understanding of where to report racism and 
racial discrimination. Survey respondents who reported having been discriminated 
against were asked further questions on how they responded to the discrimination, 
whether they had reported it, and satisfaction with how reports were handled. 


---

A/80/469
 
5/16
25-20593 
 
12. The 2024 survey results demonstrated that racism and discrimination continue 
to be prevalent concerns for Secretariat staff. Results remained largely consistent with 
trends measured by previous staff engagement surveys starting in 2021. Twenty-five 
per cent of respondents in 2024 felt that they were not guaranteed equal opportunities 
at work due to a number of factors, including race, skin colour and national or ethnic 
origin. Findings also showed that 33 per cent of those respondents who reported that 
they had been discriminated against indicated that critical incidents or misconduct 
were not reported due to a lack of trust in the reporting system, with 48 per cent 
indicating a fear of retaliation. Over half of respondents who indicated that they had 
reported cases expressed dissatisfaction with how incidents were resolved. 
13. The results of the 2024 staff engagement survey demonstrate the need for 
continued engagement with staff and stakeholders on all three pillars of the work of 
the Anti-Racism Office (advocacy and awareness-raising, transparency and 
institutional reform, and accountability and racial justice) to improve perceptions and 
experiences related to racism and racial discrimination in the Secretariat.  
 
 
 
Special Adviser’s engagement with staff and the United Nations system 
 
14. To advance the strategic action plan and directly engage with United Nations 
staff and leadership in the field, the Special Adviser undertook a mission to Ethiopia, 
Kenya and Somalia from 28 April to 6 May 2025. The mission was aimed at evaluating 
progress in implementing the strategic action plan and better understanding staff 
experiences and perceptions of racism in the workplace. It included engagements with 
personnel in the Economic Commission for Africa, the United Nations Environment 
Programme, the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat), the 
United Nations Office at Nairobi, the United Nations Support Office in Somalia and 
the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia. 
15. During these engagements, staff members raised several issues, pointing to 
structural disparities across various recruitment and human resources management 
practices, as well as incidents of overt racist behaviour in the workplace which have 
led to significant mental health issues. A prevalent fear of retaliation still prevents 
many from coming forward to report incidents of racial discrimination. More broadly, 
staff members relayed fear and uncertainty about the impact of UN80 reforms on 
them, which might have a disproportional impact on people of colour. In response, 
the Special Adviser reiterated that, as the Organization underwent restructuring, it 
must be highly aware of and actively guard against reproducing old racial hierarchies. 
Ultimately, the success of this reform hinged on its ability to decisively correct 
historical exclusions, rather than inadvertently entrench them.  
16. Specific concerns raised by staff included stalled implementation of the strategic 
action plan and marginalization in relation to mobility and access to global roles. Staff 
have spoken openly – often identifying themselves – about racial bias in deployment 
and promotion, lack of inclusive leadership development, exclusion of General 
Service staff and contractors from anti-racism efforts, and fears that UN80 reforms 
could reverse recent gains. Some staff felt that training and travel opportunities were 
also clouded by perceptions of racial bias. On a positive note, one anti-racism 
advocate created the Supporting Holistic Anti-Racism Efforts (SHARE) Team, which 
was recognized as a model to be replicated in other entities. 
17. The Special Adviser also convened hybrid town hall meetings that reached 
personnel in the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, the Department of 
Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, the Department of Peace Operations, 
the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, the Department for General 
Assembly and Conference Management, the Department of Global Communications, 
the Department of Safety and Security and the Development Coordination Office. The 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
6/16 
 
Special Adviser also held virtual town hall meetings for the United Nations Assistance 
Mission in Afghanistan and the United Nations Mission in South Sudan. At these 
meetings, concerns raised by staff included subtle but entrenched racism in 
recruitment and daily interactions, denial of racism by some managers, burden-of-
proof challenges, exclusion of national staff perspectives, elitism favouring graduates 
of prestigious global North universities, and tokenistic implementation of diversity 
measures. At one such meeting, specific allegations of racism were raised openly 
against a manager who was in the room. 
18. Across all duty stations, staff consistently requested stronger accountability 
mechanisms. They also directed complaints and reported racism to the Special 
Adviser and occasionally to the Anti-Racism Office, despite neither being mandated 
to process them. Submissions included allegations of racial discrimination in the 
workplace and racial bias in appointments and promotions, and, where appropriate, 
formal complaints were shared with OIOS for proper follow-up and investigation. 
However, in many instances staff members just wanted to share their experiences and 
refused to lodge formal complaints due to a lack of trust in the system of 
administration of justice and fear of potential reprisals.  
19. 
Beyond the Secretariat, the Special Adviser delivered a presentation to the United 
Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination in Santiago in May 2024, 
highlighting the urgency of addressing racism across the United Nations system and of 
promoting a coordinated response. She further engaged with agencies, funds and 
programmes through the Geneva Alliance against Racism and participated in the senior 
women’s leadership retreats organized by the Deputy Secretary-General, to advance 
discussions on inclusive leadership and accountability. The Special Adviser also met 
with heads of United Nations agencies, funds and programmes based in East Africa 
during her visit to Nairobi. In addition, the Special Adviser’s team gave briefings on 
the work of the Anti-Racism Office at multiple orientation programmes organized by 
the United Nations System Staff College for Junior Professional Officers across the 
United Nations system.  
 
 
 
Analysis of recent staff composition 
 
20. In the absence of race-related data in the Organization’s enterprise systems, 
geographical regions of Member States are used as a proxy. It is crucial to 
acknowledge that geographical regions of Member States as a proxy for race-related 
data do not provide a full understanding of racial identity. It is also understood that 
geographical regions are not homogeneous and exhibit a degree of racial diversity. 
While the data analysis does not directly measure the impact of systemic and 
structural racism on the Organization’s recruitment policies, processes and 
procedures, it does offer valuable indicative evidence regarding the application of the 
staff selection system based on geographical regions of Member States. The analysis 
follows a similar approach to that in the reports of the Secretary-General on the 
composition of the Secretariat: staff demographics. 
21. 
To implement its mandates, the Secretariat relied on a workforce of 35,231 as at 
31 December 2024, including 881 staff who supplemented the workforce with

III. Activities undertaken to address racism and racial 
discrimination in the United Nations Secretariat 
 
 
27. The Secretary-General’s strategic action plan on addressing racism and 
promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat is the road map for targeted 
actions to combat racism and racial discrimination at the interpersonal, institutional, 
structural and systemic levels. The Anti-Racism Office has been spearheading the 
implementation of the strategic action plan using resources approved by the General 
Assembly in its resolution 78/253. 


---

A/80/469 
 
25-20593
10/16 
 
28. The Anti-Racism Office continued to implement the strategic action plan through 
its three-pronged approach, consisting of the following action pillars: advocacy and 
awareness-raising; transparency and institutional reform; and accountability and racial 
justice. The Office undertook its activities in collaboration with anti-racism advocates 
and relevant partners across the Secretariat. To promote engagement, coordination and 
complementarity and to prevent duplication, the Office convenes several recurring 
meetings: quarterly meetings with anti-racism advocates, principals of relevant 
entities involved in implementing the strategic action plan, and working-level, 
thematic working groups tied to the three aforementioned action pillars; biannual 
meetings with staff unions, national staff associations, and staff affinity groups such 
as the United Nations People of African Descent and the United Nations Asia Network 
for Diversity and Inclusion; and an annual retreat that brings together all designated 
actors from various entities involved in the implementation of this mandate. In 
addition, the Special Adviser annually convenes and chairs three meetings of the 
Implementation Steering Group, which is composed of senior United Nations leaders 
and external experts and provides high-level guidance for the activities of the 
Anti-Racism Office and its partners across the Secretariat. All these meetings provide 
structured frameworks for multiple stakeholders to discuss, build and coordinate 
synergies towards the effective implementation of the strategic action plan.  
29. As requested by the General Assembly in its resolution 78/253, the Anti-Racism 
Office has refined the strategic action plan. This refinement does not aim to replace 
the existing action plan but rather to provide an update focused on three key areas: 
 
• Ensuring that the plan is focused exclusively on addressing racism and racial 
discrimination 
 
• Updating the definitions of critical concepts related to racism and racial 
discrimination to account for evolving understandings 
 
• Including additional implementation actions 
The refinement of the strategic action plan was undertaken through a consultative 
process with the anti-racism advocates and other relevant stakeholders in the Secretariat. 
30. The activities undertaken by the Anti-Racism Office in collaboration with its 
partners in the Secretariat and the broader United Nations system during the reporting 
period are presented below under headings corresponding to the three action pillars. 
 
 
 
A. Advocacy and awareness-raising 
 
 
31. 
Through activities aimed at raising awareness about racism and racial 
discrimination, as well as fostering dialogue and learning, the work under this pillar is 
focused on changing the organizational culture and building a workplace free of racism. 
32. In terms of training, the Anti-Racism Office, in collaboration with the Office of 
Human Resources, finalized the Secretariat’s first ever course on racism, entitled 
“Addressing racism and racial discrimination in the workplace”, which was launched 
on 4 December 2025 in English and French, with other official languages to follow. 
This online self-paced basic awareness course is intended to be made mandatory for 
all personnel.  
33. The Anti-Racism Office also organized, in collaboration with an external 
consultancy firm, various anti-racism training programmes in 2023, 2024 and 2025. 
These were directed at specialized groups such as the anti-racism advocates, senior 
leaders, managers at the D-1 and D-2 levels, staff counsellors, conduct and discipline 
officers, investigators, human resources chiefs, legal officers and members of the 
Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services. Topics included 


---
